title: Branislav Bogosavac’s CV
text:
Software Developer

branislavbogosavac@linkedin.com



Working as an intern for Leavitt Software Solutions


Python, C, C++, C#, HTML, CSS, JS, Kotlin, MySQL



Front-end deveolpment, machine learning applications







Inventory Management System

Developed a Python-based inventory management system for small businesses, facilitating real-time tracking of stock levels and automating reorder processes.

E-commerce Website

Led the development of a responsive e-commerce website using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, resulting in a 20% increase in online sales within the first quarter of launch.






2013-2017 Belgrade Gymnasium - Belgrade, Serbia
2021 - now Brigham Young University - Idaho - Rexburg, Idaho



English, Serbian, Russian, German, Ancient Greek



2022 - Present Software Developer Intern, Leavitt Software Solutions

Collaborate with cross-functional teams to develop and maintain software solutions for client projects.
Participate in Agile development processes, including sprint planning, daily stand-ups, and retrospectives.
Contribute to code reviews and provide constructive feedback to improve code quality and maintainability.



Last updated: May 2024

title: Client Report - Introduction
text:
Introduction


Elevator pitch
TODO:paste your elevator pitch here REMOVE ME: ELEVATOR PITCH IS A SHORT (3-5 SENTENCES) PARAGRAPH THAT DESCRIBES KEY INSIGHTS TAKEN FROM METRICS IN THE PROJECT RESULTS THINK TOP OR MOST IMPORTANT RESULTS.
The project explores the relationship between the size of the engine and the highway fuel efficiency. By examinig a dataset of various car models, we discover a notable correlation between the two. Larger engine sizes tend to result in lower highway miles per gallon, and smaller engine sizes tend to result in higher highway miles per gallon.


QUESTION|TASK 1
TODO:COPY PASTE QUESTION|TASK 1 FROM THE PROJECT HERE
1.Finish the readings, setup, and be prepared with any questions to get your environment working smoothly (class for on-campus and Slack for online)
I have finished the readings and setup.


QUESTION|TASK 2
TODO: COPY PASTE QUESTION|TASK 2 FROM THE PROJECT HERE
2.In VS Code, create the example chart from section 3.2.2 of the textbook. (Note: you will be using Plotly Express to display the chart instead of Altair which is used in the book)
TODO: type your results and analysis here
From the following chart we can see the relation between the “hwy” and “displ.” “hwy” stands for highway miles per gallon (mpg), which is a measure of fuel efficiency for vehicles when driven on highways. “displ” stands for engine displacement, which is the total volume of all the cylinders in a nengine. Engine displacement is an important factor in determining the power and performance characteristics of an engine. From the analysis of the data chart, we see the trend the larger the engine- smaller the fuel efficiency, and smaller the engine- better the fuel efficiency.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here

import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px

mpg = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4python4ds/master/data-raw/mpg/mpg.csv")

chart = px.scatter(mpg, x='displ', y='hwy')  

chart.show()


                                                




QUESTION|TASK 3
TODO: COPY PASTE QUESTION|TASK 3 FROM THE PROJECT HERE
3.Your final report should also include the table created from the following (assuming you have mpg from question 2)
TODO: type your results and analysis here
From the following table we see the summary of four of the properties of the dataset we are working with. It displays the first five data objects, specifying the manifacturer, model, year and the highway miles per galon for each vehicle.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
(mpg
  .head(5)
  .filter(["manufacturer", "model","year", "hwy"])
)
